item.title: Lockdown: Boris Johnson unveils plan to end England restrictions by 21 June
item.description: Shops, hairdressers, gyms and outdoor hospitality could reopen on 12 April, Boris Johnson says.

item.title: Holiday bookings surge following lockdown exit plans
item.description: Travel agencies and airlines say website traffic jumped following Boris Johnson's announcement.

item.title: 'Resist becoming numb to the sorrow' - Biden
item.description: President Joe Biden addresses the nation as the US mourns 500,000 people lost to Covid-19.

item.title: El Chapo's wife Emma Coronel Aispuro arrested in US over 'drug trafficking'
item.description: Emma Coronel Aispuro's arrest comes two years after her husband was convicted in the US over his cartel.

item.title: Nasa reveals new video from Mars Perseverance Rover
item.description: The American space agency has released stunning video of its Perseverance rover landing on Mars.

item.title: Extinction: Freshwater fish in 'catastrophic' decline
item.description: Numbers are plunging due to pollution, unsustainable fishing and the draining of rivers.

item.title: Alex Salmond alleges 'malicious' attempt to damage him
item.description: In a written submission to Holyrood the former first minister names people he claims attempted to damage his reputation.

item.title: Keir Starmer urges government to buy more food from British farmers
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer will be the first Labour leader to address the farmers' union since 2008.

item.title: Climate change a grave security threat - Boris Johnson
item.description: David Attenborough and activist Nisreen Elsaim are to address a UN session chaired by Boris Johnson.

item.title: Hayley Arceneaux: Cancer survivor joins first all-civilian space mission
item.description: The SpaceX mission will make Hayley Arceneaux the first person with a prosthesis to visit space.

item.title: Gender-reveal device explosion kills father-to-be
item.description: Christopher Pekny was making a device to be used at his child's gender-reveal party, police say.

item.title: Jeep pushed to retire Cherokee name from SUVs
item.description: The chief of the Cherokee Nation says 'it's time' for corporations to stop using native American names.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Pupils in secondary schools in England will be required to wear masks in class.

item.title: How can children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 16 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Vaccine passports: Do I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The growing number of people vaccinated may be able to gain more freedoms in the future.

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: The Papers: 'Midsummer's dream' and '118 days until freedom'
item.description: Tuesday's front pages are dominated by the prime minister's plan to ease England's lockdown.

item.title: Augmented reality art: Where your home becomes the gallery
item.description: How virtual artworks allow you to see anything from the sun to a giant spider in your own home.

item.title: 500,000 deaths: The 'colourful' lives lost to Covid
item.description: The sheer scale of the US death toll is hard to comprehend - it helps to hear the individual stories.

item.title: Sarika Kale: The sports star who could afford just one meal a day
item.description: Sarika Kale says she survived on instant noodles and chutney for years because that's all she could afford.

item.title: Church of England Vicar ‘games for God’
item.description: A London vicar says he was "called by God" to create the virtual 'Church of Chat'.

item.title: 139-year-old Victorian house moved in San Francisco
item.description: The Victorian building was moved six blocks, but it was not a simple journey.

item.title: Little Mix video call for five-year-old Stevenage fundraiser
item.description: Amaya gets to speak to her musical idols as a treat for raising money for homeless people.

item.title: The Muppet Show: Disney adds content warning over 'negative stereotypes'
item.description: A disclaimer is running ahead of 18 episodes of The Muppet Show, which is streaming on Disney Plus.

item.title: Dating apps scam committed by criminal from inside prison
item.description: A recently reformed criminal shares how he ran romance scams to serve as a warning to others.

item.title: Is it worth tracking your carbon footprint?
item.description: Apps that offer to track your carbon footprint are becoming more common, but are they any good?

item.title: Covid US death toll: Imagining what 500,000 lost lives look like
item.description: Half a million Americans have died of the coronavirus. Here's a look behind this grim milestone.

item.title: Roadmap: 'We're delighted to have dates to work towards'
item.description: Boris Johnson’s route out of lockdown is a relief for businesses, including pubs, restaurants, gyms and retail.

item.title: Mask force: London's five centuries of face coverings
item.description: Not a new normal: A brief history of five centuries of face masks.

item.title: 'They wanted to jail a banker - I was that banker'
item.description: Tom Hayes, jailed for rigging interest rates, tells the BBC fresh evidence will show his conviction was unsafe.

item.title: Lockdown review: What are the risks of schools, pubs and shops reopening?
item.description: Lockdown in England will be lifted in stages - what are the risks associated with relaxing certain restrictions?

item.title: Measuring Africa’s Data Gap: The cost of not counting the dead
item.description: Just eight countries in Africa have adequate death registration systems, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: The video call apps linking home workers with strangers
item.description: A number of tech firms are connecting people working from home with strangers via video calls.

item.title: 'Coins can inspire people to look into the past'
item.description: BBC News website readers share their old coin collections and the stories behind them.

item.title: Over-The-Rhine: Is this a model for urban renewal or a warning sign?
item.description: In Cincinnati's Over-The-Rhine neighbourhood, does urban revitalisation come at a cost?

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Don't ask me which vaccine is best, please
item.description: Dr John Wright says he's often asked which vaccine is best, but the answer is it's too early to say.

item.title: 'A robbery of the points' - late Benteke winner leaves Brighton in 'danger zone'
item.description: Christian Benteke's late goal gives Crystal Palace a dramatic Premier League win at rivals Brighton, who are now in threat of being drawn into a relegation battle.

item.title: Up to 10,000 fans could return to stadiums by mid-May
item.description: Up to 10,000 fans could be back in stadiums by mid-May as part of the government's plans to move England out of lockdown.

item.title: Josh Warrington: Mauricio Lara rematch could be make or break for career
item.description: British featherweight Josh Warrington explains why he wants to face Mauricio Lara again in a make-or-break rematch.

item.title: Giles & Porter in GB Euro Indoors squad but Asher-Smith out with injury
item.description: Elliot Giles, Keely Hodgkinson and Tiffany Porter are among the names in Britain's European Indoor Championships squad.

item.title: Murray 'didn't want to see' Australian Open after being forced to miss it
item.description: Andy Murray is not surprised by Novak Djokovic's Australian Open win against younger opponent Daniil Medvedev.

item.title: England v Northern Ireland: Lionesses cannot wait to return, says Steph Houghton
item.description: Steph Houghton says players "can't wait to put on the England shirt again" against Northern Ireland after a 12-month wait.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Schools reopening: How at risk are children?
item.description: BBC's Health reporter Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: When will I able to go to the gym or get a haircut, in England?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
item.description: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.
